Question: How to "check" a cast?: :I wrote a method that gets a random value from a Map. I first got all the values in the map and use a Random object to get a random one. Here is the method:public static <K, V> V getRandomValInMap (Map<K, V> map) {    Collection<V> values = map.values ();    V[] array = (V[])values.toArray ();    return array[random.nextInt (array.length)];}In the expression(V[])values.toArray ()Android Studio said that it is an "unchecked cast from Object[] to V[]". So I guess this is kind of "risky". I tried using another overload of toArray:V[] array = new V[values.size()];array = values.toArray (array);And I guess this is not how you would use the overload because there's a compiler error saying that I cannot initialize V.So I think maybe I should use the first method. But how do I "check" a cast to cancel the warning?Or, you can tell me how to use the toArray(T[] array) overload correctly.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer: ASSISTANT:
response:
<<<api>>>: Java API
<<<code>>>: public static <K, V> V getRandomValInMap (Map<K, V> map) {    Collection<V> values = map.values ();    V[] array = (V[])values.toArray ();    return array[random.nextInt (array.length)];}
<<<explanation>>>: The cast `(V[])values.toArray()` is an unchecked cast, which means that the compiler does not verify if the cast is valid at runtime. To avoid the warning, you can use the `Iterator.next()` method to get the value from the map instead of using the `toArray()` method with an unchecked cast. Here's an example of how to use `Iterator.next()`:
```java
public static <K, V> V getRandomValInMap (Map<K, V> map) {
    Iterator<V> iterator = map.values().iterator();
    if (iterator.hasNext()) {
        V value = iterator.next();
        return value;
    } else {
        throw new NoSuchElementException();
    }
}
```
This way, you avoid the unchecked cast and also handle the case where the map is empty.
